title: JFK and The Unspeakable -Why He Died  2008
description:
JFK and The Unspeakable -Why He Died  2008


James Douglass is bracing us to reimagine John F. Kennedy around the 50th anniversary of his â€œrendezvous with death.â€ Heâ€™s encouraging us to face what has seemed to me a central question â€” not so much the â€œWho Killed JFK?â€ bumper-sticker, but more â€œWhy canâ€™t we know?â€ The answer, Jim Douglas says, is â€œunspeakable.â€ Heâ€™s adopting a code-word that the late Trappist monk and author Thomas Merton applied to the eternal enemy, â€œthe void,â€ darkness iself, â€œsystematic evil that goes beyond the imagination.â€ Douglassâ€™s â€œunspeakableâ€ is the multifarious modern Satan which took the form of a movement in the upper reaches of Kennedyâ€™s own national security state to kill the president as he made a radical and inspired turn toward peace. He has written a conspiracy book with a scholarâ€™s footnotes and a theological subtext. And a robust Oliver Stone endorsement.

Douglassâ€™s JFK and the Unspeakable is a meticulous compilation of Kennedy and assassination studies. I came to it late, five years after publication, on the recommendation of friends sharing a precious secret. Itâ€™s a shocker that has the air, throughout, of a deeply serious inquiry. Jim Douglass has his own temperate, good-humored air. Born in Canada, heâ€™s lived many years in Birmingham, Alabama as a Catholic Worker peace activist and soup-kitchen friend of the down-and-out, all the while teaching himself how to research and write history
